name: question_1813783_5ad018655f709bbc25f55df282068edb
question: Identify the followingSleep Stages.A)   The stage of sleep associated with dreams is[ Select ]["Sleep 1", "Sleep 2", "Slow Wave Sleep", "REM"].B)   Spindles and K complexes are intermittent bursts of high frequency or voltage observed during[ Select ]["Sleep 1", "Sleep 2", "Slow Wave Sleep", "REM"].C)[ Select ]["Sleep 1", "Sleep 2", "Slow Wave Sleep", "REM"]is characterized by its highly synchronized activity.D)[ Select ]["Sleep 1", "Sleep 2", "Slow Wave Sleep", "REM"]is also known as paradoxical sleep due to its contradictory nature (i.e., active, desynchronized brain, but paralyzed body).E)[ Select ]["Sleep 1", "Sleep 2", "Slow Wave Sleep", "REM"]shows the most de-synchronized pattern of activity.F)[ Select ]["Sleep 1", "Sleep 2", "Slow Wave Sleep", "REM"]shows the lowest rate of change in mean EEG per unit time.

name: question_1813785_5ad018655f709bbc25f55df282068edb
question: The sequence of activation that initiates dream sleep goes from the[ Select ]["occipital cortex", "pons", "lateral geniculate"]to the[ Select ]["occipital cortex", "pons", "lateral geniculate"]and then on to the[ Select ]["occipital cortex", "pons", "lateral geniculate"].[ Select ]["ACh", "Dopamine", "GABA"]is the[ Select ]["inhibitory", "excitatory"]neurotransmitter that is released to desynchronize the brain during this wave of activation.Unlike during waking arousal, stimulation enters[ Select ]["the front of", "the rear of", "from below"]the cortex during this phase of sleep.During this phase, there is also an active suppression by the brainstem of motor activity, called[ Select ]["paradoxical sleep", "atonia", "rapid eyemovement"].

name: question_1813788_5ad018655f709bbc25f55df282068edb
question: Indicate whether the following are TRUE or FALSE of the Circadian Rhythm.A)   The Supra-Chiasmic Nucleus shows a pattern of activity on a 24 +/1 hour cycle.[ Select ]["True", "False"]B)   The Pineal Gland hangs right below the Hypothalamus.[ Select ]["True", "False"]C)   The sleep aid, melatonin, stimulates activity in the Pineal Gland.[ Select ]["True", "False"]D)   Melanopsin is the neurotransmitter released along the Retino-Hypothalamic Path.[ Select ]["True", "False"]E)   Ancient ganglion cells in the retina act as receptors that register changes in ambient light levels.[ Select ]["True", "False"]F)   The SCN releases Serotonin onto the Pineal Gland.[ Select ]["True", "False"]G)   The Pineal Gland increases its melatonin production as the light fades.[ Select ]["True", "False"]H)   Receptor axons synapse in the SCN which then signals the Pineal Gland.[ Select ]["True", "False"]
